questions.question: What is the main difference between a Pushdown Automaton (PDA) and a Turing Machine?

answers.a: PDA has a stack while Turing Machine has a tape
answers.b: PDA is deterministic while Turing Machine is non-deterministic
answers.c: PDA can only read input while Turing Machine can read and write
answers.d: PDA has finite states while Turing Machine has infinite states

explanations.a: Correct: PDA uses a stack for memory while Turing Machine uses an infinite tape that can be read from and written to.
explanations.b: Incorrect: Both can be deterministic or non-deterministic.
explanations.c: Incorrect: While this is partially true, the main difference is the memory structure (stack vs tape).
explanations.d: Incorrect: Both have finite sets of states.

questions.question: What does the Church-Turing thesis state?

answers.a: All computers are equivalent to Turing machines
answers.b: Any computation that can be algorithmically performed can be computed by a Turing machine
answers.c: Turing machines are the fastest computational model
answers.d: All programming languages are Turing complete

explanations.a: Incorrect: This is too broad and not the precise statement of the thesis.
explanations.b: Correct: The Church-Turing thesis states that any computation that can be algorithmically performed can be computed by a Turing machine or equivalent model.
explanations.c: Incorrect: The thesis is about computational capability, not speed.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Not all programming languages are Turing complete.

questions.question: How many components are in the formal definition of a Turing Machine?

explanations.a: Incorrect: A Turing machine has more than 5 components.
explanations.b: Incorrect: A Turing machine has more than 6 components.
explanations.c: Correct: A Turing machine is formally defined as a 7-tuple (Q, Σ, Γ, δ, q₀, q_accept, q_reject).
explanations.d: Incorrect: A Turing machine has exactly 7 components in its formal definition.

questions.question: What does the symbol Γ (Gamma) represent in a Turing Machine?

explanations.a: Incorrect: The input alphabet is represented by Σ (Sigma).
explanations.b: Correct: Γ (Gamma) represents the tape alphabet, which includes the input alphabet and additional symbols.
explanations.c: Incorrect: The set of states is represented by Q.
explanations.d: Incorrect: The transition function is represented by δ (delta).

questions.question: What is the key characteristic of a Deterministic Turing Machine (DTM)?

answers.b: It can move in both directions on the tape
answers.c: For any state-symbol combination, there is exactly one possible transition

explanations.a: Incorrect: A basic DTM has one tape, though multi-tape variants exist.
explanations.b: Incorrect: While DTMs can move in both directions, this is not the defining characteristic.
explanations.c: Correct: In a DTM, for any given state and tape symbol, there is exactly one defined transition.
explanations.d: Incorrect: DTMs may not always halt (halting problem).

questions.question: What does it mean for a system to be 'Turing complete'?

answers.a: It can solve any problem in polynomial time
answers.b: It has the computational power to simulate a Turing machine
answers.c: It can only solve decidable problems
answers.d: It is faster than a Turing machine

explanations.a: Incorrect: Turing completeness is about computational capability, not time complexity.
explanations.b: Correct: Turing completeness means a system can simulate any Turing machine and perform any computation that is theoretically possible.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Turing complete systems can attempt to solve undecidable problems (though they may not halt).
explanations.d: Incorrect: Turing completeness is about capability, not speed.

answers.b: A decidable problem that determines if a program will terminate

explanations.d: Incorrect: The Halting Problem is about termination, not optimization.

questions.question: Which class of languages can Turing Machines recognize?

explanations.a: Incorrect: Turing machines can recognize more than just regular languages.
explanations.b: Incorrect: Turing machines can recognize more than just context-free languages.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Turing machines can recognize more than just context-sensitive languages.
explanations.d: Correct: Turing machines can recognize the class of recursively enumerable languages, which is the most general class.

questions.question: What happens when a Turing Machine reaches an accept state?

answers.c: It accepts the input and halts
answers.d: It moves to the reject state

explanations.a: Incorrect: When a Turing machine reaches an accept state, it halts.
explanations.b: Incorrect: Reaching an accept state means the input is accepted, not rejected.
explanations.c: Correct: When a Turing machine reaches an accept state, it accepts the input and halts computation.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Accept and reject states are mutually exclusive.

questions.question: Why are two stacks equivalent to a Turing machine tape?

answers.a: Two stacks provide more memory than one stack
answers.b: Two stacks allow access to any middle element by transferring between stacks
answers.c: Two stacks are faster than one tape
answers.d: Two stacks can store more symbols

explanations.a: Incorrect: It's not about the amount of memory but the access pattern.
explanations.b: Correct: With two stacks, you can access any middle element by pouring elements from one stack to another, simulating random access like a tape.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Speed is not the reason for equivalence.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Storage capacity is not the key factor.

questions.question: What is the transition function δ (delta) in a Turing Machine?

answers.a: A function that determines the initial state
answers.b: A function that maps current state and tape symbol to next state, write symbol, and head movement
answers.c: A function that determines if the input is accepted
answers.d: A function that counts the number of steps

explanations.a: Incorrect: The initial state is q₀, not determined by δ.
explanations.b: Correct: The transition function δ maps (current state, tape symbol) to (next state, write symbol, head direction).
explanations.c: Incorrect: Acceptance is determined by reaching accept states, not by δ directly.
explanations.d: Incorrect: δ doesn't count steps, it defines transitions.

questions.question: What is computability in the context of Turing machines?

answers.a: The speed at which a Turing machine operates
answers.b: Whether a problem can be solved by following a finite sequence of well-defined steps
answers.c: The amount of memory a Turing machine uses
answers.d: The number of states in a Turing machine

explanations.a: Incorrect: Computability is not about speed but about the possibility of computation.
explanations.b: Correct: Computability refers to whether a problem can be effectively computed by following algorithmic steps, as modeled by Turing machines.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Computability is not about memory usage.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Computability is not about the number of states.
